instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1466: What is A1466? A1466 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Early 2015, 2017, Mid 2012, Mid 2013, Early 2014 with EMC 2925, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00165, 820-3209, 820-3437..
definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PP1V05_SUS: What is PP1V05_SUS? The PP1V05_SUS signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that supplies 1.05 volts, typically used in a suspended (SUS) state of the laptop. This state is a low-power mode where essential system functions are maintained, but the majority of the system is powered down..
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no power
threads.message:
Hi, I have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B that the client report that stoped working without no reason

I have green light, fan spin, CPU gets hot, and get voltages on big coils.

I have:

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> = 5V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> = 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> = 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_SUS</SIGNAL> =1.06V
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL> = 1.5V
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> = 1.74V

Can it be BIOS?
Can you help?[B][/B]

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no power
threads.message:
Could be BIOS, even bad CPU.
Check first if <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is high.
Also check for USB activity.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no power
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL>  is high (3.3V) and no USB activity

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no power
<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no power
threads.message: Can't find no Clean ME on the forum. Do you have itt please? Do i need to change the serial, even on clean me?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no power
threads.message:
Do not change anything, just test.
If works, then serial can be changed.
Then Fsys must be also fixed, of course.
[URL unfurl="true"]https://drive.google.com/file/d/1_vUaRGjasq1rYvM6pfckGOvb-ljLB7FT/view?usp=sharing[/URL]

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no power
threads.message:
Hi, 
With this BIOS I don't get fan spin, and on PSU it goes a few times from 120mV to 20 mV

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no power
threads.message:
That file is marked as good.
Verify after write.
Be sure to flash it properly.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no power
threads.message:
II should have done something wrong in the first flash. 

After re-flashed bios I get fan spin, but no USB  activity.  
<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL>  = 3.3V, CPU gets hot and it consume arround 0.550 V on PSU

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no power
threads.message:
Check all SPI Bus Series Termination resistors and their traces.
Also check the resistors from LPC bus.
